action.action-desc: Mr. Espaillat (for himself, Ms. Sherrill, and Mr. Lynch) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To amend title 49, United States Code, to authorize state of good repair grants to be used for public transportation resilience improvement, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Resilient Transit Act of 2022.
Section 5302 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (17) through (25) as paragraphs (18) through (26), respectively; and
by inserting after paragraph (16) the following:
The term resilience improvement has the meaning given the term in section 176(a) of title 23.

section.header: State of good repair grants for public transportation resilience improvement

subsection.text: Section 5337 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may make grants under this subsection to assist State and local government authorities in financing 1 or more eligible activities described in paragraph (2).

subparagraph.text: A recipient of a grant under this subsection may use grant amounts for public transportation resilience improvements that increase the resilience of public transportation systems from the impacts of changing conditions, such as sea level rise, flooding, wildfires, extreme weather events, and other natural disasters.
Activities eligible to be carried out using grant amounts under this subsection include—

clause.text: the installation of mitigation measures that prevent the intrusion of floodwaters;
the installation of equipment to detect the occurrence of a flood event;
the replacement of equipment or facilities that are currently prone to flood events or will be in the future;
the purchase of new equipment to support regular maintenance of drainage and pumping infrastructure;
the replacement of equipment stressed during extreme temperature events;
the installation of equipment to regulate temperatures and sensors to monitor extreme temperatures;
the development of backup systems to provide redundancy during the outage of a primary power source;
the assessment of system vulnerabilities to current and future weather events, natural disasters, and changing conditions, including sea level rise;
the planning of system improvements and emergency response strategies to address identified vulnerabilities; and
any other activity for resilience improvement, as determined by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Grants under this subsection may be used to finance—

subparagraph.text: components of projects carried out under subsection (b)(1).

paragraph.text: Of the amounts made available under section 5338(a)(2)(L) to carry out this subsection—

subparagraph.text: 97.15 percent shall be apportioned to recipients in accordance with subsection (c); and
2.85 percent shall be apportioned to recipients in accordance with subsection (d).

subsection.text: Section 5337 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking section 5338(a)(2)(K) each place it appears and inserting section 5338(a)(2)(L).

section.text: Section 5338(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (B), by striking $13,634,000,000 and inserting $13,934,000,000;
in subparagraph (C), by striking $13,990,000,000 and inserting $14,290,000,000;
in subparagraph (D), by striking $14,279,000,000 and inserting $14,579,000,000; and
in subparagraph (E), by striking $14,642,000,000 and inserting $14,942,000,000; and
by inserting and $300,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2023 through 2026 shall be available to carry out section 5337(g) after section 5337(f).
